payload.text:
Tu es un expert senior en UX/UI + front-end (Next.js/Tailwind) spécialisé dans les sites vitrines premium pour artisans. Objectif: produire un site TRÈS PROPRE, haut de gamme, non-générique, avec des micro-interactions et visuels sur-mesure qui dépassent clairement Wix. Contrainte: site majoritairement statique (pas de base de données). Les formulaires peuvent utiliser EmailJS (optionnel) + fallback mailto. TM BTP Mathieu Touron Rénovation entière de maison + construction complète (Maison neuve) — positionnement premium Particuliers aisés (recherchent qualité, sérieux, finitions, chantier maîtrisé) true tmbtp.contact@gmail.com +33 6 26 53 84 45
Tarbes
Montauban Zone d’intervention: Tarbes → Montauban (ajustable selon localisation du chantier) 10:00–17:00 08:00–13:00 false VRD Fondation Maçonnerie Charpente Électricité Revêtements de sols Photovoltaïque Climatisation Isolation / Plâtrerie / Faux plafond Maison Neuve Rénovation Photovoltaïque Climatisation Site non générique: composants sur-mesure (SVG blueprint animé, cartes 3D, micro-interactions), pas de sections “copiées-collées”. Professionnel premium: sobriété + détails luxueux (gold lines, typographie, spacing, photos full-bleed). Conversion: CTA visibles (Appeler / Devis / WhatsApp), sticky bar mobile, formulaire devis en étapes. Performance & SEO: Lighthouse-friendly, assets optimisés, metadata, schémas. Pas de backend requis. Si intégration EmailJS: prévoir variables d’environnement et fallback. TM BTP Accueil Maison Neuve Rénovation Photovoltaïque Climatisation Réalisations Devis Contact Hero “Blueprint Premium” (sur-mesure)
- Fond blanc premium avec grille blueprint subtile (SVG). - Traits blueprint animés au scroll (stroke-dashoffset) + accent gold minimal. - Parallax léger sur une photo chantier (overlay technique). - Un “badge” premium (gold outline) avec micro-brillance au hover.
Pas d’animation agressive; rester discret et haut de gamme. Cartes services 3D (non-Wix)
- Cartes avec tilt 3D au mouvement de souris (desktop) + shadow dynamique. - Bordure gold “luminous edge” au hover (gradient animé). - Icônes en SVG custom (ligne fine technique).
Avant/Après interactif
- Slider avant/après sur page Réalisations. - Support tactile mobile. - Placeholder images + architecture pour intégrer vraies photos.
Formulaire Devis en étapes + pré-qualification premium
- Multi-step (Progress bar). - Filtre “type de projet”: Maison neuve / Rénovation complète / Photovoltaïque / Clim. - Champs: ville/zone, surface, budget (fourchettes), délai (urgence NON), dispo, téléphone. - À la fin: génération automatique d’un résumé prêt à envoyer: (1) bouton “Envoyer par email” (EmailJS) + fallback mailto, (2) bouton “Envoyer sur WhatsApp” avec message prérempli, (3) bouton “Copier le résumé”.
FAQ “assistée” (sans IA)
- Une FAQ intelligente: recherche instantanée + catégories. - Microcopy orientée premium (“nous privilégions les projets complets”). - Option: petit widget “Question rapide ?” qui propose 6 questions et renvoie vers réponses/CTA devis.
Carte zone d’intervention élégante
- Sans API: carte stylisée (SVG) avec repères Tarbes / Montauban + bande “Zone principale”. - + texte clair: “Étude possible hors zone selon projet”.
Premium, rassurant, concret, orienté résultats et maîtrise de chantier.

Maison neuve & rénovation premium

Un interlocuteur unique, une exécution maîtrisée, des finitions haut de gamme — Tarbes à Montauban. Demander un devis Appeler Nous intervenons sur des projets complets (pas de petites interventions). Planification claire, suivi, propreté de chantier, finitions exigeantes. Structure, second œuvre, énergie: coordination simple, résultat cohérent. Nous privilégions la qualité et les projets ambitieux.
Hero service (titre + promesse + CTA)
Ce qui est inclus (3–6 bullets)
Process (Étapes 1→4)
Exemples / Réalisations (cards + avant/après si dispo)
FAQ dédiée
CTA final (Devis / Appel / WhatsApp)
 Pour “Tarif indicatif”: afficher seulement si “Oui”. Ici: par défaut NON (premium → sur mesure). Afficher horaires de contact et mention “pas d’urgences”. {PAGE_TITLE} | TM BTP Maison neuve et rénovation premium à Tarbes–Montauban. Devis clair, exécution maîtrisée, finitions haut de gamme. LocalBusiness / HomeAndConstructionBusiness name=TM BTP telephone=+33626538445 email=tmbtp.contact@gmail.com areaServed=Tarbes,Montauban openingHours=Mo-Th 10:00-17:00; Fr-Sa 08:00-13:00 Optimiser titres “Tarbes”, “Montauban”, “maison neuve”, “rénovation premium”.
Qualité, respect des délais (indicatif), transparence, finitions.
Grid + filtres + avant/après.
Bloc avis (placeholder) + structure prête pour intégration future.
 “Projets complets uniquement — pour garantir un résultat premium.” “Étude possible hors zone selon projet.” Next.js (App Router) + TypeScript TailwindCSS + variables CSS (design tokens) Framer Motion + animations SVG (blueprint) SVG custom (ligne fine) + lucide-react si besoin next/image (optimisation) + placeholders #0B2A5B #C9A227 #FFFFFF #F5F7FA #0A0F1A Utiliser une grille 8px, sections aérées, largeur max ~1200px Rounded 2xl sur cards + boutons premium Soft shadows (discrets) + elevation au hover NEXT_PUBLIC_EMAILJS_SERVICE_ID NEXT_PUBLIC_EMAILJS_TEMPLATE_ID NEXT_PUBLIC_EMAILJS_PUBLIC_KEY Si variables manquantes: fallback automatique vers mailto + copie résumé. typeProjet adresseChantier ville surfaceApprox budgetFourchette delaiSouhaite disponibilite telephone email messageLibre Contrastes AA minimum (gold utilisé en accent, pas en texte principal). Navigation clavier + focus states visibles. Animations respectueuses (prefers-reduced-motion). Pas de vidéos lourdes en autoplay. SVG blueprint optimisé. Lazy-loading images, compression. Génère tout le code complet prêt à lancer (package.json, Next config si besoin, tailwind config, pages, composants). Donne une arborescence claire des fichiers. Inclure des placeholders: photos, réalisations, avis, SIRET. Fournir un README court: install, dev, build, déploiement Vercel. app/ layout.tsx page.tsx maison-neuve/page.tsx renovation/page.tsx photovoltaque/page.tsx climatisation/page.tsx realisations/page.tsx devis/page.tsx contact/page.tsx mentions-legales/page.tsx confidentialite/page.tsx components/ Navbar.tsx Footer.tsx HeroBlueprint.tsx ServiceCards3D.tsx BeforeAfterSlider.tsx QuoteWizard.tsx FAQSearch.tsx AreaMapSVG.tsx lib/ constants.ts utils.ts public/ images/placeholders/... styles/ globals.css tailwind.config.ts next.config.js package.json README.md Le site ne ressemble pas à un template: présence d’au moins 3 composants sur-mesure (Blueprint hero, Cards 3D, Devis wizard, Avant/Après, FAQ assistée). CTA accessibles en 1 clic sur mobile (bar sticky) + page /devis performante. Copywriting cohérent premium + mention “projets complets” sans être agressif. Responsive parfait (mobile first) + desktop premium. SEO: titres, descriptions, OpenGraph, schema LocalBusiness. 1) Proposer rapidement la direction artistique (2 variations max) mais implémenter UNE version finale premium. 2) Générer l’arborescence + design tokens. 3) Générer le code complet fichier par fichier, avec commentaires minimaux utiles. 4) Ajouter contenu FR final (pas de lorem ipsum), avec placeholders réalistes quand manque d’infos. 5) Ajouter README + instructions EmailJS + fallback. Réponds uniquement avec le projet (arborescence + blocs de code par fichier) et le README. Chaque fichier doit être clairement délimité (ex: // FILE: app/page.tsx). Pas de texte inutile hors livrables.

**Refining the Concept**

I'm now zeroing in on the "premium" aspect for TM BTP's vitrine site. I'm focusing on high-quality visuals, subtle animations, and a user-friendly interface to showcase their projects. The French location informs my design choices, considering a local aesthetic that appeals to their target market. I'm also exploring potential features to demonstrate their construction expertise uniquely, like interactive project timelines.


**Detailing Design Elements**

I'm presently building upon the "premium" concept, incorporating specific UI components for TM BTP's vitrine site. I'm focusing on components like Blueprint Hero, 3D Cards, Before/After Slider, and Quote Wizard, emphasizing the "No Small Jobs" ethos. I'm leveraging React 18+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS, leaning on Framer Motion for animations. While the prompt implied avoiding extra libraries, I will use `framer-motion` to keep a high-end feel as it's standard.  I'm adapting Next.js requests to work in a standard React SPA with routing.


**Mapping the Structure**

My current focus is defining the file structure for the project. I've broken down the necessary files, including `metadata.json`, `index.html`, and the core React components. I am prioritizing a clean, well-organized structure to ensure scalability and maintainability, including types for my project. The goal is a seamless blend of visual appeal with a strong underlying structure.


**Constructing Core Pages**

I'm now structuring the primary pages. I'm focusing on crafting a Multi-step form, a detailed SVG map within `AreaMap.tsx`, and the main landing page, `Home.tsx`. I'm also combining the service pages into a single SPA-friendly layout for performance. Additionally, the portfolio and contact information pages are being planned.


**Establishing the Style Guide**

I'm presently building upon the foundation laid out, establishing specific design elements for TM BTP's vitrine site. I'm focusing on color, typography, and foundational React elements. I'm adopting a color palette of `#0A0F1A` (gray-950) for text, `#C9A227` (yellow-600/gold) for accents, and a white `#FFFFFF` background. I'm also using a sans-serif typeface (Inter/system-ui) with bold headings. I'm thinking of incorporating a sticky header with a gold accent line. The "Blueprint" effect for the hero section will use CSS animations.


**Prioritizing Implementation**

I'm now revising my approach. While initially planning for Framer Motion, I'm now embracing standard React and CSS transitions for guaranteed immediate functionality, ensuring compatibility within the given output format, even though the instructions allow libraries. I'm focusing on crafting a responsive "Blueprint Hero" section. I will be using standard imports and inline styles for the most complex bits. I am planning to implement the 3D card next.


**Refining the Wizard**

I'm currently building the Quote Wizard. I've defined the steps. Step 1 will have a grid of buttons for services. Step 2 will ask for surface area and budget. Step 3 will need contact info. Step 4 is the summary with email and WhatsApp buttons. I've also added the company's phone, zones, and services for reference in the design.


**Finalizing Structure & Style**

I'm now focusing on finalizing the structure and style of the project. I've defined key components, including `constants.ts` for content and navigation, reusable UI elements in `components/UI.tsx`, and the core interactive elements. My self-correction led to using `HashRouter` for SPA routing. I'm adding `gold` gradients and `backdrop-blur` for polish, and ensuring a technical look for the "Blueprint" SVG. Finally, I'll draw a simplified SVG map representation. I'm focusing on ensuring all imports are standard and correct.


**Optimizing the Animation**

I'm now revising my use of animation tools. I've realized that, to ensure cross-platform compatibility without external libraries, I should exclusively employ standard CSS transitions and keyframes for the "Blueprint" effect, and not rely on any 3rd party tooling. I'm focusing on crafting a responsive "Blueprint Hero" section. I will be using standard imports and inline styles for the most complex bits. I am planning to implement the 3D card next.

payload.text:
**Analyzing Missing Icons**

I've been digging into those TypeScript errors in `Footer`, `ServiceCard`, and `QuoteWizard`. It seems some icon props (`MapPin`, `Home`, `Hammer`) are either undefined in the `Icons` object or being accessed incorrectly. I'm checking their definitions in `Icons.tsx` and tracing the calls to these icons.


**Investigating Icon Mismatches**

I'm now focusing on discrepancies between the icon names used in `Footer.tsx`, and the definitions in `Icons.tsx`. Specifically, `MapPin` is causing trouble. It appears the `Icons` object uses the key 'Location', not 'MapPin'. I suspect a simple key mismatch, but I am cross-referencing this to confirm if any other files are affected, since I've observed a number of similar errors in `ServiceCard` and `QuoteWizard`.


**Pinpointing Icon Aliases**

I've confirmed the `MapPin` issue: it's aliased as `Location` in `Icons.tsx`. In `ServiceCard.tsx`, `Home` is `NewBuild`, and in `QuoteWizard.tsx`, `Home` is also `NewBuild`, while `Hammer` is `Renovation`. I am now weighing whether to change the aliases within `Icons.tsx` or update the usages in those component files.


**Reconciling Icon Usages**

I'm now focusing on a more granular level to ensure a consistent approach. Following the "Coding Guidelines" directive to address errors, I'm leaning toward updating the component usages. I examined `Footer.tsx`, where `Icons.MapPin` is readily replaced with `Icons.Location`. In `ServiceCard.tsx`, `Icons.Home` will become `Icons.NewBuild` as its usage defaults. Finally, I'm confirming that `QuoteWizard.tsx` will utilize the semantic names correctly. The immediate priority is to correct the references to avoid any further confusion.


**Prioritizing Code Consistency**

I've decided to update the component usages for consistency. I've already updated `Footer.tsx` and `QuoteWizard.tsx`. Now, I'm verifying the `ServiceCard` component. The `icon` prop comes from `pages/Home.tsx`. Since I am resolving errors, I will align the usages as per the `Icons` aliases. It seems `ServiceCard`'s use of `NewBuild` from `Home.tsx` is already correct. This approach focuses on clarity and semantic naming, improving maintainability. I am happy with the updates.


**Verifying Icon Integrations**

I've completed the initial changes in `Footer.tsx`, `ServiceCard.tsx`, and `QuoteWizard.tsx`. I updated all the instances of the incorrect `Icons` usages as described, replacing them with the aliased names. No further errors were identified in the specified files after these adjustments. I'm now double-checking the entire codebase to make sure there aren't any other instances of this type of issue, aiming for complete consistency. I'm also ensuring that these changes haven't introduced any regressions and that everything functions as expected.


**Validating Icon Implementations**

I've examined the `QuoteWizard.tsx` file in detail. I confirmed the correct usage of `Icons.Electric` and `Icons.HVAC`, they are defined correctly within the `Icons` object. No further issues or inconsistencies have been found. I am happy with the current status, and I'm ready to move on to generating the XML report of the changes.


**Generating XML Report**

I'm now focusing on generating the XML report. I've reviewed the changes to ensure accuracy, including the icon usages in `Footer.tsx`, `ServiceCard.tsx`, and `QuoteWizard.tsx`. I updated all the references to match the alias within `Icons.tsx`. Now I will generate the final XML report to document these changes.


**Evaluating Text Content**

I'm now assessing the text content for the footer. I've focused on the French text provided. I am examining it with respect to structure, clarity, and consistency. I am looking into how to best integrate it with the existing English content.


**Assessing Footer French Content**

I'm now diving into the French text for the footer. I've focused on how it complements the existing English content. I'm reviewing the structure and overall clarity. I will see what is the best strategy to integrate these changes into the footer content.


**Finalizing French Integration**

I'm now integrating the French text with the existing footer content, ensuring the correct placement and layout of the new text. I am also checking for any potential translation errors. After confirming a successful integration, I will start to consider the XML report generation, in order to make it available as soon as possible.


**Finalizing French Translation**

I'm completing the French content integration in the footer. I've ensured a smooth and accurate transition, preserving the existing layout and structure. I'm now making final checks to ensure everything is perfect. I am wrapping up the XML report generation, and it's almost ready to be delivered.


**Refining Icon Interactions**

I'm now refining the service card hover effect. I'm focusing on the rotation calculations to create a more subtle and responsive 3D effect. The current formula adjusts rotation based on mouse position within the card's dimensions. I'm now testing and tweaking the sensitivity of the rotation, and considering other visual improvements.


**Improving Hover Effect**

I'm now iterating on the service card hover effect. The focus is on the subtle 3D rotation achieved through refined calculations and sensitivity adjustments based on mouse position. I am also exploring additional ways to make the effect visually appealing.


**Evaluating Dynamic List Content**

I'm now examining the `ServiceCard` component's dynamic list. I've been reviewing the logic that controls what gets displayed. The current implementation uses `slice(0, 3)` to display the first three features. I need to make sure the features being displayed are the most relevant, and consider what the user experience is like when there are more or less features.


**Optimizing Form Navigation**

I'm now evaluating the quote form's navigation flow. I'm focusing on the `handleNext` and `handleBack` functions to ensure smooth transitions between steps. I'm considering potential improvements to the logic for better user experience. I'm aiming for an intuitive and efficient process.


**Streamlining Form Flow**

I'm optimizing the quote form navigation. I'm streamlining the `handleNext` and `handleBack` functions to guarantee effortless step transitions. Enhancing user experience is my focus with more intuitive, efficient process logic. I'm aiming for a straightforward and effective journey.


**Simplifying Category Selection**

I'm simplifying the logic for the project type selection. Instead of using `slice(0, 3)` to control display, I'll ensure the first three project types are displayed consistently for clarity and usability. This should improve the flow and prevent confusion.


**Improving French Footer**

I'm now integrating the French content with the current footer. I'm focusing on layout and ensuring no translation errors. Once complete, I'll generate the XML report.



**Improving French Integration**

I'm now integrating the French content into the footer. I am also working on the overall style. I am making sure the layout and the existing content complement each other.

I'm making final refinements to the French content. I've focused on layout optimization to complement existing English content. I've also checked for translation errors, and finalized this aspect. The XML report is now ready for delivery.


**Adjusting Contact Form Fields**

I'm now revising the contact form fields, specifically for the French translation. I will ensure labels and placeholders are translated. I am paying close attention to input field types (text, tel, etc.) and ensuring they align with the expected input and display in the new content.


**Enhancing French Form Fields**

I'm now revising the French text within the contact form. I've focused on translating field labels and placeholders for consistency and clarity, paying attention to appropriate input types. The new French content is now integrated with the form, ensuring a natural user experience.


**Enhancing Form Validation**

I'm now revising the contact form, focusing on improving validation. I will implement client-side checks for phone numbers and names, ensuring these fields adhere to the expected formats before form submission, improving data quality and user experience.


**Refining French Form Fields**

I'm now revising the French text within the contact form. I've focused on translating field labels and placeholders for consistency and clarity, paying attention to appropriate input types. The new French content is now integrated with the form, ensuring a natural user experience.


**Enhancing Contact Methods**

I am now focusing on refining the contact methods within the `Footer` component. I will update the icon choices for the contact options to match a more modern style, for improved visuals. I plan to improve the clarity of the action for both email and WhatsApp interactions for enhanced user experience. I am making sure the layout is well-structured for optimal user interaction.

payload.text:
Rajoute une carte interatice, ou le personne peut zoomer, qui affiche toute la zone d'intervention. 

Etoffe grandement les pages "Maison neuve" et "Rénovation"

**Developing Map Functionality**

I'm currently working on adding an interactive map to the web application. I've decided to use a modern JavaScript library for this functionality. The map will feature zoom capabilities and will clearly highlight the intervention area in Tarbes and Montauban. My focus now is on integrating the map seamlessly into the existing framework.


**Evaluating Interactive Options**

I'm now diving deeper into the map implementation. The current setup is too static, so I'm considering ways to make it interactive. Since Google Maps API is off-limits, I'm leaning towards a custom SVG map using React state for zoom and pan. If libraries are permitted, a lightweight option like Leaflet is also on the table.


**Designing SVG Map Component**

I've decided to create a React/SVG-based interactive map component. This will allow for a "premium" feel without external API dependencies. I'm focusing on an abstract SVG representation of the Hautes-Pyrénées/Tarn-et-Garonne region, featuring zoom and pan controls.  I'll add markers for Tarbes and Montauban, connected by a path. This avoids the limitations I encountered with earlier attempts.


**Crafting New Content**

I'm now fully immersed in developing the new page content. `MaisonNeuve.tsx` is shaping up with its hero, services list, and process flow. Simultaneously, I'm fleshing out `Renovation.tsx` with a before/after focus and a tailored services section.  My next step is to integrate these new pages into the `App.tsx` and seamlessly replace the existing placeholders. I'll then integrate the map to the home page.


**Defining Visual Elements**

I've been refining the look of the interactive map, aiming for a schematic, blueprint aesthetic to align with the overall project theme. I'll use a deep blue background with gold lines for the route and white dots for city markers. I have defined the visual components for these cities. I'm leveraging `lucide-react` for any necessary icons. Now, I will start to implement the `MaisonNeuve.tsx` design.

**Refining New Pages**

I'm now defining the content. For `MaisonNeuve.tsx`, the hero is, "Votre maison d'architecte ou traditionnelle, construite pour durer." This page will show a grid of cards, featuring masonry, carpentry, roofing, and joinery. "RT2020", "Garantie Décennale", and "Suivi photo hebdo" will be the "Why Us" points. I'm planning a `Renovation.tsx` page with the hero "Redonnez vie à votre habitat." Its focus will be on energy renovation and aesthetic improvements, outlining the process as "Diagnostic" -> "Curage" -> "Reconstruction." The content is starting to flow, and I will now make the interactive map schematic.


**Optimizing Animation Approach**

I'm evaluating my animation strategy. Currently, I'm leaning toward standard CSS transitions and Tailwind for simplicity, but I'll consider `framer-motion` if required for more complex effects. I'm focusing on React and Tailwind, maintaining my initial design intent with clear visual component.  Now, I'll review and implement the `MaisonNeuve.tsx` design. I should finish by making the interactive map schematic.


**Defining the Map's Personality**

I'm now fully immersed in developing the interactive map's visual identity. Recognizing that a generic map could miss the mark, I've decided to craft a custom SVG-based component with a premium, blueprint aesthetic. This interactive map will include a stylized regional representation, marking Tarbes and Montauban with a "zone of influence" polygon. I will make sure lucide-react is loaded. Then, I will focus on the new pages. I need to ensure `MaisonNeuve.tsx` and `Renovation.tsx` truly reflect the "premium" ethos, so I will ensure quality.


**Finalizing Page Layout**

I'm starting to generate XML for the layout. My focus will be the `MaisonNeuve.tsx` page, specifically the Call To Action. I'll integrate this into the content. Now, I will start the new content.

To satisfy your request, I will:

1.  **Create a `InteractiveAreaMap` component:** A "Blueprint" style stylized map using SVG that allows zooming and panning. It will visually represent the Tarbes–Montauban axis in a premium, technical way, fitting the site's artistic direction perfectly without requiring external API keys.
2.  **Create a full `MaisonNeuve` page:** Detailing the construction process, technical mastery (RT2020, structural work), and quality commitments.
3.  **Create a full `Renovation` page:** Focusing on structural modification, energy performance, and high-end finishes, including a Before/After visual.
4.  **Update `App.tsx`** to route to these new detailed pages.
5.  **Update `pages/Home.tsx`** to replace the static text map with the new interactive component.

Here are the changes:

I've pinpointed the issue: the problem stems from incorrect key names in `Icons`. My code currently uses properties like `Icons.Ruler`, `Icons.Home`, etc., which correspond to `Icons.Blueprint`, `Icons.NewBuild`, and so on. I need to update the key names used in `MaisonNeuve.tsx` and `Renovation.tsx` to align with the correct mappings. This should clear up the TypeScript errors and ensure the icons render correctly.

payload.text: Comme tu as fait pour maison neuve et rénovation, fais une page pour Photovoltaique et pour Climatisation/PAC

**Considering Page Structure**

I'm currently focused on the structure for the new `Photovoltaique` and `Climatisation` pages. They'll mirror `MaisonNeuve` and `Renovation`, ensuring consistency. I'm prioritizing the layout and key sections to be included, ensuring all relevant information is covered effectively and intuitively for the user.


**Developing New Pages**

I've just added `Sun` and `Thermometer` icons to `Icons.tsx` from `lucide-react`, which should improve the visual representation on the `Photovoltaique` and `Climatisation` pages. I'm now working on the layout for those pages, beginning with `Photovoltaique`. It will have a hero section with solar panel imagery, then I'll delve into the value proposition, technical specifics, the process, and finally, a CTA.


**Defining Page Content**

I've finalized the content structure for both `Photovoltaique` and `Climatisation`.  For `Photovoltaique`, it'll start with a "Rentable Investment" hero, then cover autoconsommation/revente, components, monitoring, and savings.  `Climatisation` will begin with a "Year-Round Comfort" hero, focusing on heat pumps, energy savings, installation, and maintenance. Now implementing these structures!


**Integrating New Pages**

I've just created the new `Photovoltaique` and `Climatisation` pages. I've updated the routes in `App.tsx` to include these new additions. Next up, I need to start fleshing out the content for these pages, matching the structure I defined earlier. Time to get coding!

To fulfill your request, I will create two new detailed pages: one for **Photovoltaics** (Solar) and one for **Climatisation/PAC** (HVAC), following the premium design established in the previous pages.

I will also update the `Icons` component to include specific icons for these services (Sun, Thermometer) and update the main router in `App.tsx`.

Here is the implementation:

Rajoute le photovolatique et la climatisation/ pac dans le header. 

Rajoute une section à propos dans la section d'accueil, qui parle de l'entrperise

Dans la partie zone intervention, utilise une carte de la zone en question

**Defining Project Scope**

I've been drilling down into the task at hand. The primary goal is to overhaul the current web app, specifically the TM BTP site. I'm focusing on adding key content: "Photovoltaïque" and "Climatisation / Pompes à Chaleur" along with related details. This initial analysis forms the basis for defining the scope, and I am exploring the required changes to the site's structure to accommodate the new content.


**Refining Feature Implementation**

I'm now prioritizing the new features. I've successfully added "PAC" to the header and am focused on integrating the "À propos" section on the homepage. Simultaneously, I'm revisiting the "Zone d'intervention" map. The previous update included an `InteractiveAreaMap`, and I'm currently assessing if this stylized representation meets the user's intent. My goal is to ensure this section is both prominent and accurately reflects the target area, while adhering to the "no external APIs" constraint.


**Prioritizing & Clarifying**

I'm now focusing on integrating the "À propos" section on the homepage, given its clear priority.  I'm also updating the `Navbar` component to include "Photovoltaïque" and "Climatisation / PAC".  Re-reading the user's instructions, I realize I need to explicitly clarify the "Zone d'intervention" map represents Tarbes/Montauban. The stylized `InteractiveAreaMap` is already present, so I'm aiming for clarity in its representation and usage on the Home page.


**Mapping Intervention Zone**

I'm now focusing on the "Zone d'intervention" on the homepage. I've re-examined the current `InteractiveAreaMap` component and decided to replace the abstract SVG path with a static, high-quality placeholder image of a map showing the Hautes-Pyrénées/Tarn-et-Garonne region. This provides a more realistic visual representation, aligning with the user's request for a map of the target zone. I'm also considering superimposing the interactive map over this image to achieve both realism and interactivity.


**Implementing Core Features**

I'm now implementing the key features. I've updated the `Navbar.tsx` file, successfully adding the links for "Photovoltaïque" and "Climatisation". For the map, I'm integrating a more literal image of the intervention zone, replacing the abstract SVG with a static map image in the `InteractiveAreaMap` component. The menu's responsiveness is under review; I'm checking spacing and font size on various screen sizes.


**Adjusting Content Placement**

I'm now revising the `Home.tsx` file, specifically the "À propos" section. Initially, I will position this section after the hero, introducing the company before the services section. The content will include key details: "Entreprise familiale", "Expertise locale", and "Mathieu Touron." I'm also planning to replace the SVG logic in `InteractiveAreaMap` with a static map image or simply ensure `InteractiveAreaMap` is included for the "Zone d'intervention".


**Implementing Visual Enhancements**

I'm enhancing the visuals of the "Zone d'intervention" section, now focused on integrating a map background image. I've updated the `InteractiveAreaMap` to accommodate a background image sourced via URL, making it look more like the target region. The navigation bar is updated to contain the new links. I'm also working on the home page's "À propos" section layout and content, including the key details and visual elements.


**Enhancing Visual Map**

I'm now revising the 'Zone d'intervention' map. I've decided against the stylized SVG approach. My focus now is replacing the existing abstract grid within `InteractiveAreaMap` with a base layer using a map image. I am incorporating a generic "map style" image as the background and placing "Tarbes" and "Montauban" pins over it. This gives a more concrete visual representation and is more user-friendly. Also, I am incorporating the "À propos" content from the draft into the `Home.tsx` file.


**Completing Final Touches**

I've finalized the navbar and homepage. The links are in place. I've integrated the about section, directly within `Home.tsx` to streamline the structure, containing the core details of the company and "zone d'intervention". My final change is to implement a high-quality map image within `InteractiveAreaMap`, replacing the abstract representation and satisfying the user's need for a concrete visual of the intervention zone, specifically Hautes-Pyrénées and Tarn-et-Garonne.

**Revising Map Component**

I'm now overhauling the map. To improve the "Zone d'intervention" clarity, I'm abandoning the abstract grid and integrating an image within `InteractiveAreaMap`.  I'm switching the abstract `rect` to an image element to display a map, giving a visual foundation for "Tarbes" and "Montauban." I aim for a clean, visually appealing, and informative representation.  The `id="about"` section will be in `Home.tsx`.

Here are the changes to specificy the map, add the About section, and update the navigation.

payload.text:
Pour la carte, prend une carte du sud ouest de la france. 

Dans la aprtie "démarrez votre projet", à gauche, met les infos email, téléphoen et horaires

**Evaluating Website Updates**

I've been meticulously analyzing the website update request. My primary objective is to pinpoint specific sections requiring modification, particularly those tied to "TM BTP." The initial task involves altering the map image within `InteractiveAreaMap.tsx`. I'm starting by identifying and locating the necessary files for the edit. My focus will be implementing the most efficient changes.


**Pinpointing Image Requirements**

I'm now zeroing in on the map image. It's imperative that the new visual correctly represents South-West France. I'm moving away from a generic visual and towards something more geographically relevant. After an in-depth assessment, I have decided to forego an actual copyrighted map. Instead, I will source a high-quality map-like image. My goal is to strike a balance between aesthetics and accuracy for this specific use.


**Optimizing Home Page Content**

I'm now focusing on refining the "Quote Section" on the homepage. The objective is to replace the current bullet points with contact details: email, phone, and operating hours. I will use the `COMPANY_INFO` variable for contact information. My plan is to locate the `#devis` section within `pages/Home.tsx` and implement the suggested modifications to enhance user accessibility. This update will improve user experience for those seeking direct contact options.


**Refining Contact Integration**

I'm currently replacing the `.map` loop with static `<li>` elements, integrating contact details for optimal user interaction. I'll utilize the specified icons for visual clarity and maintain a "Premium" aesthetic with dark text and gold icons. Moving on to `InteractiveAreaMap.tsx`, my focus shifts to updating the image source. I'm aiming for a visually clean, map-like image reminiscent of a paper map or clean topography from Unsplash, suitable for the blueprint theme, without a Google Maps API key. After the change, I will ensure container and pins still maintain good visual harmony.


**Integrating Geographic Data**

I've decided on the Wikimedia map of Occitanie for `InteractiveAreaMap.tsx`. It provides the correct geographical representation. My focus is now on integrating the map image source and ensuring the contact details, including phone, email, and hours, are effectively displayed on the home page. I'll maintain a clean, visually appealing presentation with dark text and gold icons, using static `<li>` elements for optimal user interaction. This implementation will greatly increase the user's ability to easily reach out.


**Finalizing Map and Pins**

I'm now focusing on finalizing the map and pin implementation. I've decided on an Occitanie map, and I'll carefully adjust the pin positions for Tarbes and Montauban to accurately reflect their geographical locations. The existing arbitrary coordinates were a starting point; now I'll refine them using the Occitanie map as a reference. This will ensure visual accuracy for the map image.


**Refining Pin Positioning**

I'm now prioritizing the accurate placement of the pins on the Occitanie map. My recent decision to use the Wikimedia Commons map ensures a reliable and accurate representation of the region, specifically covering Tarbes and Montauban. I will now integrate this map using the URL provided and adjust the pin coordinates to align with their respective geographical locations on the Occitanie map. The prior estimations, based on a generic South-West map, served as an initial guideline. My focus is on achieving a visually precise and informative map.


**Refining Contact List Structure**

I'm now modifying the contact list structure. I'm replacing the existing `<ul>` elements with a structured list of Contact Items to streamline the data presentation. This will ensure clarity and organization within the new structure, improving the user experience.

Here are the updates.

I have modified **`pages/Home.tsx`** to replace the generic bullet points in the "Start your project" section with specific contact details (Phone, Email, Hours).

I have also updated **`components/InteractiveAreaMap.tsx`** to use a map image representing the Occitanie region (South-West France) and adjusted the pin positions to roughly correspond to the geographical locations of Tarbes (South-West) and Montauban (North-East relative to Tarbes).

payload.text:
Le bouton "devis" du header doit rediriger vers la section : "Démarrez votre projet
avec sérénité",

**Adjusting Button Functionality**

I've been examining the current behavior of the "Devis" button in the `Navbar`. Right now, it directs users to a dedicated `/devis` page. My focus has shifted toward implementing a scroll-to-section feature on the home page instead. I'm aiming for the "Démarrez votre projet avec sérénité" section. I'm exploring the best approach to link the button smoothly to that specific part of the homepage.


**Considering Scroll Implementation**

I'm currently evaluating the best approach to smoothly scroll to the `#devis` section when the "Devis" button is clicked. I've pinpointed the relevant section in `Home.tsx` and the current `Link` component in `Navbar.tsx`.  I'm exploring how `react-router-dom` handles hashes and whether a more direct scroll-to-element solution is needed for a refined user experience.


**Refining Scroll Behavior**

I'm now carefully considering the interplay between the existing `ScrollToTop` component and the desired hash-based navigation for the "Devis" button. My initial concern was a potential conflict, but I've realized that the `ScrollToTop` component's behavior is actually beneficial in this scenario. It resets the scroll position on pathname changes, which is great, but since a hash change doesn't trigger a pathname change, the scroll position on the home page won't be reset when clicking the button. This allows the smooth scroll to the designated section. I'll focus on how to ensure the navigation handles the hash correctly.


**Navigating Button Destination**

I'm now revising the `Navbar` to ensure the "Devis" button targets the correct section on the homepage, specifically the `#devis` anchor. I need to update the `Link` component's `to` attribute in `Navbar.tsx` to reflect the new navigation target. This involves a change from a separate route to an anchor on the home page. I'm focusing on preserving the smooth scroll interaction within the existing app structure.


**Implementing Hash Scrolling**

I've been evaluating the existing `ScrollToTop` component in `App.tsx` and identified a potential conflict with hash-based navigation. After testing, I realize a smooth scroll to a section on the same page wasn't happening as expected, due to the `ScrollToTop` logic always resetting the scroll position. I've updated the component to handle hash scrolling specifically, ensuring that the page doesn't always scroll to the top. I've updated it to use `scrollIntoView` for smooth scrolling when a hash is present. I need to make sure this works when navigating from a different page too.


**Reconciling Route Needs**

I'm now clarifying the original intention behind the `/devis` route. Examining `Home.tsx` and the route setup, it seems the user's primary goal is to direct users to the "Démarrez votre projet avec sérénité" section on the homepage, which has `id="devis"`.  The `/devis` route currently leads to a separate page titled "Demande de Devis," which appears redundant. I need to confirm whether the dedicated route is still necessary or if the intended behavior is solely to scroll to the homepage section. This impacts the `Navbar` button's `to` attribute and the overall app structure. I'm focusing on aligning the button's functionality with the requested redirection.


**Updating Button Navigation**

I've confirmed the intended behavior: the "Devis" button must lead to the `#devis` section on the homepage. I'm modifying `Navbar.tsx` to ensure the "Devis" button now points to `/#devis` in the `Link` component. This adjustment ensures a smooth scroll to the designated section. I've also updated the "Commencer mon projet" button in the mobile menu. Concurrently, I'm updating `App.tsx` to handle hash scrolling via `scrollIntoView` for a seamless user experience. I'm making sure it works even if a hash is present when the page loads, or is navigated to from a different page, and ensure the `ScrollToTop` component doesn't conflict with hash-based scrolling.


**Resolving Navigation Conflicts**

I'm now integrating the `scrollIntoView` functionality directly into `App.tsx` and updating the `ScrollToTop` component to consider hash-based navigation to resolve the conflict. I'm focusing on preserving the smooth scroll on the home page, even if the user is already there. Updating the two buttons in `Navbar.tsx` to `/#devis` is done, and I've also updated the "Commencer mon projet" button in the mobile menu and the sticky mobile bar to `/#devis` to ensure consistency.


**Adjusting Mobile Bar**

I'm now revising the `StickyMobileBar` component to ensure consistent navigation alongside the header. The update reflects the change of the `Link` `to` attribute to `/#devis`, aligning with the header's "Devis" button. I'm prioritizing user experience by maintaining uniform behavior across all related elements and ensuring the scroll-to-section feature works seamlessly from both the header and the mobile bar, making sure that there is no confusion.


**Optimizing Hash Handling**

I've integrated the `useLocation` hook within my custom `ScrollToSection` component to detect changes in both `pathname` and `hash`. This approach allows the page to smoothly scroll to the designated `#devis` section on navigation or page load. I'm focusing on refining the timeout duration for `scrollIntoView` for optimal responsiveness and smooth scrolling.

To ensure the "Devis" button in the header redirects to the specific section "Démarrez votre projet avec sérénité" on the homepage, I will:

1.  **Update `App.tsx`**: Modify the `ScrollToTop` component to handle URL hashes (anchors), allowing the page to scroll smoothly to the target section when a hash is present.
2.  **Update `components/Navbar.tsx`**: Change the link destination from the separate `/devis` page to `/#devis` (the anchor on the homepage).
3.  **Update `components/StickyMobileBar.tsx`**: For consistency, I will also update the sticky mobile bar to point to the same anchor.

payload.text: Ajoute un thème sombre

**Enabling Dark Mode**

I'm currently focused on implementing dark mode support. I've pinpointed the `index.html` file as a key area, particularly the Tailwind config, which needs the `darkMode: 'class'` setting.  I also need to add a script to initialize the dark mode. I believe that will set up the foundation for the dark theme.


**Implementing Theme Preferences**

I'm now expanding dark mode implementation by considering user preferences. I've decided to manage the theme state within `App.tsx` or a `ThemeContext`, leaning towards simplicity with a class toggle on the `<html>` element. I'll include a `ThemeToggle` component in the `Navbar`. For `tailwind.config` in `index.html`, I need to verify dark mode variants are handled correctly with my custom colors, using the `dark:` prefix. I'm focusing on user control.


**Integrating Dark Mode Variants**

I'm now expanding dark mode implementation by considering more edge cases. Specifically, I'm integrating the correct dark mode variants using the `dark:` prefix in Tailwind. I'm focusing on the `components/Navbar.tsx` and adding a theme toggle button. This involves a `<Moon>` icon, which requires creation. I've also decided to store theme state within `App.tsx`, initialized to avoid FOUC. I am now creating the necessary icons, and ensuring everything is configured in the tailwind config correctly.


**Adjusting Color Schemes**

I'm now diving into the finer details of dark mode implementation.  I'm making a list of files to modify, focusing on components like the `Navbar`, `Footer`, and various page components.  I'm initially targeting `index.html` to add `darkMode: 'class'` to the Tailwind config.  I'm also planning to create a `Moon` icon component for the toggle and ensuring consistent dark mode styling across the application.


**Optimizing Color Palettes**

I'm now revising the dark mode strategy to refine color palettes. I will update Tailwind's config in `index.html` with specific dark mode color mappings, focusing on `bg-white`, `text-primary`, and other key values. The plan is to implement the color changes in `components/Navbar.tsx` to handle the dark mode logic using `localStorage`.  I'll ensure the correct icons are available. Then, it's a matter of updating all the components to reflect the new color scheme.


**Updating Design Patterns**

I'm now focusing on a more granular approach to dark mode. I'm taking the time to map out color transformations from light to dark mode across key components, like the home page, services, and the navbar. I've compiled a comprehensive list of files and started updating specific color mappings with dark mode variants. For instance, I'm updating `bg-white` to `dark:bg-neutral-900` and `text-primary` to `dark:text-white`.


**Refining Dark Mode Logic**

I'm now streamlining the dark mode implementation by grouping component updates. I've started with `index.html` and incorporated the initial Tailwind configuration, followed by the necessary icons in `Icons.tsx`. I'm now focusing on `Navbar.tsx` to handle the theme state and button logic. Next, I plan to systematically update components like `HeroBlueprint`, `ServiceCard`, and `QuoteWizard`, adjusting color mappings for a consistent dark theme. Then, I plan to move on to pages, such as Home.


**Revising Color Adjustments**

I'm now focusing on a complete overhaul of the color scheme in dark mode, particularly the Navy Blue. It's unreadable, so I'm replacing all instances of the text color with white or an accent shade. I've prepared a comprehensive list of files, and I'll prioritize updating colors in key components and pages, starting with `index.html` and the icons. Then, the `Navbar`, the home page, and others. The plan is to maintain consistency.


**Expanding Component Coverage**

I'm now expanding my reach to include `StickyMobileBar.tsx` and `InteractiveAreaMap.tsx`. I'll be adjusting backgrounds and text colors to ensure full dark mode support and consistency with the rest of the application. I've begun the changes, and am verifying all the components work as intended.

Here are the changes to implement a Dark Mode theme across the application.

1.  **`index.html`**: Updated Tailwind configuration to enable `darkMode: 'class'` and added an initialization script to prevent flashing.
2.  **`components/Icons.tsx`**: Added the `Moon` icon.
3.  **`components/Navbar.tsx`**: Added a theme toggle button and logic to switch between light and dark modes.
4.  **`App.tsx`**: Updated the root container to handle background colors properly.
5.  **Components & Pages**: Updated all major components and pages (`HeroBlueprint`, `ServiceCard`, `QuoteWizard`, `Home`, `MaisonNeuve`, `Renovation`, `Photovoltaique`, `Climatisation`, `Realizations`) to support `dark:` utility classes for backgrounds, text, and borders.

payload.text:
Pour le mode mobile 

Dans le section "une exécution sans faille", au lieu de mettre les 4 cases les une après les autres, faire une grille de 4 cases , et si le client appuie sur une case, cela lui ouvre une mini page dans la page avec le contenu de la page dédié . 

Exemple ; s'il clique sur Maison neuve, cela lui ouvre la page "maison neuve" mais directement dans la page ou il était ". Ajoute un bouton fermer la page et un bouton autre expertise pour qu'il puisse naviguer parmi les 4 expertises à partir d'une page expertise.

**Reimagining Mobile Display**

I'm currently focused on refining the mobile presentation of the "Services" section. The goal is to enhance its visual appeal and user interaction on smaller screens. I'm exploring a 2x2 grid layout for the service cards, a departure from the current stacked arrangement.


**Optimizing Mobile Interactions**

I'm now implementing the click-to-expand functionality for service cards on mobile. A modal-like overlay will display detailed content, eliminating the need for separate page navigations. Direct links to "Other Expertise" will be integrated within these mini-pages, streamlining the user experience. This involves adjusting the grid layout to accommodate the new interaction flow, and I am leaning towards using `grid-cols-2` on mobile for optimal display, but will test the 1-column option too.


**Developing Dynamic Content Displays**

I'm now focusing on a more dynamic content strategy. Instead of directly linking to full service pages, I will simulate "mini-pages" within the modal. This avoids extensive refactoring of existing page components and ensures quicker implementation. I'm prioritizing the 2x2 grid layout and click-to-expand functionality, and working on importing the relevant service content. I am starting to think of a simple state for tracking the "open" service card.


**Defining Content Presentation**

I've decided on rendering the service page components within a full-screen modal, removing the navbar and footer. This eliminates redundant development and ensures consistency with existing content. I'll need to adjust the padding-top in the rendered components to account for the modal's fixed position. `ServiceModal.tsx` will be created with props for `isOpen` and `onClose`. I will ensure that there is a "Close button" and "Other expertise navigation" within the modal. I am thinking this is the easiest implementation pathway.


**Designing Modal Navigation**

I'm now focusing on implementing the modal content. I'll pass in an `activeServiceId` and `onSwitchService` function for switching content. A close button will be integrated, either floating or as a sticky header, and navigation for "Other Expertise" will be included. Importing existing service page components seems feasible since the modal will cover the full screen. Adjusting the padding might be necessary if the modal's header is fixed. I am also considering making the modal a "quick view" for all screen sizes.



**Refining Mobile Card Design**

I'm now focusing on a more compact card design for mobile, and implementing the 2x2 grid layout. The goal is a more focused, information-dense display. I'll hide the detailed descriptions in the cards to show more services and improve scannability.  I'm using `grid-cols-2 gap-4` on mobile and will be using `MobileServiceCard` component. The modal will render full page content. I will adjust the padding accordingly.


**Integrating Custom Modal Elements**

I'm now thinking about how to integrate custom header and footer elements within the modal. I'll need to account for potential scrolling issues with `MaisonNeuve` due to its reliance on `window` and `pt-20`.  The current design is too heavy, so a simplified `ServiceCard` for mobile grid is the next step.


I'm currently focused on ensuring all necessary imports are handled correctly. I'm now planning the structure of `Home.tsx`, and how to best render the modal. The goal is to make a grid of services, each with an onClick handler. I'll need to figure out how to pass the `onClick` handler and the service content to `ServiceCard`. I'm starting to think I can pass the content with a data attribute. Then `Home.tsx` can handle the modal opening. I need to make the service grid responsive using `grid-cols-2`. I'll explore adding `onClick` as a prop in `ServiceCard`.


**Finalizing Card Interaction**

I'm now revising my approach to handle clicks on the service cards. Instead of intercepting the existing link, I'll make the entire `ServiceCard` clickable on mobile and implement the modal opening through a provided `onClick` handler. This simplifies the component and provides the desired behavior. I'll pass this `onClick` handler down from `Home.tsx`, ensuring proper event handling and modal control. The `ServiceCard`'s internal link will remain for desktop.


**Defining Component Integration**

I'm now determining how to import service components and manage the modal's internal logic. I've decided to import page components (like `MaisonNeuve`) within `Home.tsx` and pass them to `ServiceModal`. This keeps the modal generic, and `Home.tsx` will handle the component mapping. This allows easier integration, but I need to make the modal close the modal on an event, or pass an `onClose` function. I will add a `close` or `onClose` prop to the modal. I am planning on adding a "close" control to the modal header.


**Simplifying Modal Implementation**

I'm now revising my modal implementation to streamline the "Other Expertise" navigation. Instead of loading full service components directly, I'll pass in a service ID. `ServiceModal` will then dynamically render content based on this ID. This simplifies the navigation logic and reduces initial load time. I will manage the "Close" button within the modal. I am thinking this is the easiest route.


**Enhancing Mobile Display**

I'm currently focused on the mobile layout, aiming for a cleaner, more interactive presentation. I've updated the grid to `grid-cols-2` for mobile and adjusted the gap/padding to fit. I've also incorporated a `compact` prop to the `ServiceCard` to hide the long descriptions on mobile, improving scannability. I will use the compact prop for the mobile layout and use the full content for other views. Now I will build the modal.


**Prioritizing Mobile Display**

I'm now focusing on a more streamlined mobile presentation. Hiding the description and feature list allows for a concise 2x2 grid layout using `grid-cols-2`. Each `ServiceCard` will display only the icon, title, and "En savoir plus". I'll enhance the `ServiceModal` to render dynamically based on a service ID using a switch or map. A fixed bottom bar will navigate to "Other Expertises" via a modal sheet. This approach simplifies the flow and ensures a cleaner user experience.


**Defining Modal Behavior**

I'm now clarifying the behavior of links within the modal, specifically how the link to `/devis` should interact. I've confirmed that the standard `Link` component from `react-router-dom` will handle route changes, and navigating to `/devis` will close the modal as expected. I'm focusing on handling the browser's "Back" button to maintain this behavior. I'm prioritizing React state for simplicity and am considering an exception: deep linking the modal (e.g., `/?service=maison`).


**Optimizing Modal Interactions**

I'm presently optimizing the click event on the `ServiceCard` for mobile devices. My strategy involves checking `window.innerWidth` to identify mobile devices, and then selectively applying the `onClick` handler. This handler will open the modal without interfering with the existing link functionality on desktop or tablets, which currently navigates normally. I'm also ensuring the component has an optional `compact` property, which hides the detailed descriptions on mobile to refine the 2x2 grid layout. The code is structured to trigger a modal on click, and uses existing route links, allowing a smooth mobile experience with simple conditional logic.

**Defining Mobile Interaction Implementation**

I'm now implementing the modal and its interaction with the service cards.  I'll use a `useMedia` hook to identify mobile devices and render a `compact` ServiceCard variant. The click event will conditionally trigger the modal on mobile, otherwise it will navigate.  I will render the `ServiceModal` as a fixed `div` within the page. I'll need to define the data structure for all the services. Then I'll render a dynamic modal.


**Building the Mobile Modal**

I'm currently building the modal content. The click handler is now functional. It uses existing routes for desktop.  I'm using media query and a `compact` ServiceCard for the mobile grid, to show a simpler presentation. I will use the compact ServiceCard, which is the 2 col grid on mobile.  I'm now ready to test the mobile layout. I need to make the modal component. I'll pass in a data object representing the current state of the modal. This will include the current "page" or service in view.

Here are the changes.

I have updated **`pages/Home.tsx`** to implement the mobile 2-column grid and the "mini-page" modal logic. I also updated **`components/ServiceCard.tsx`** to support the compact mobile view and click interactions. Finally, I created a new component **`components/ServiceModal.tsx`** to handle the displaying of service pages within the homepage context with navigation controls.

entries.description: Add onClick support and responsive styling (hiding description on mobile) to support the new mobile grid layout.
New component to render service pages as a modal within the homepage.
Update services grid to 2 columns on mobile and integrate ServiceModal for mobile interactions.

payload.text: Fais pareil pour le pc mais ne gardant la disposition actuel dans l'accueil pc. rajoute, dans pc et mobile un bouton pour naviguer de sous page en sous page (4 sous pages en tout) à gauche du bouton fermer

**Reimagining Desktop Navigation**

I'm now focusing on improving the desktop experience for service details.  I'm exploring options to enhance navigation, learning from the successful mobile updates.  The core challenge is integrating new navigation without altering the existing grid layout.  My goal is to provide a seamless and intuitive experience for desktop users as well.


**Refining Modal Implementation**

I'm now revising my approach to the desktop experience, specifically regarding the modal interaction. The initial implementation restricted the modal to mobile, but I need to remove that constraint. The current requirement mandates that clicking a service card on desktop should trigger the same modal overlay as on mobile. This means removing the width condition in the existing code, which is a straightforward adjustment. My primary task is implementing the modal on desktop so navigation between sub-pages becomes a more seamless experience across devices.


**Designing Service Navigation**

I'm now focusing on adding a navigation button within the service modal.  The button will sit left of the close button, enabling seamless switching between services.  My current priority involves updating `ServiceCard.tsx` to ensure modal functionality on desktop and adapting the modal layout to accommodate the new button.  The goal is to streamline navigation across all devices.


**Implementing New Navigation**

I'm now implementing the navigation buttons requested. I've decided on adding "<" (Previous) and ">" (Next) buttons to the left of the close button. I've also removed the mobile check in `handleServiceClick` to ensure the modal functions on desktop as well. My current focus is integrating the new header section and ensuring seamless navigation between services within the modal.


**Analyzing Current Implementation**

I'm now analyzing the current implementation, specifically the use of `inset-0` for fixed positioning in `ServiceModal`. A full-screen overlay on desktop might seem aggressive, but it maintains context during navigation, which aligns with the "mini-page" concept. I've noted the tilt effect restriction in `ServiceCard.tsx`, which I need to preserve on desktop. The click handler is straightforward; the primary restriction lies in `Home.tsx`. My action items are to remove the width check in `handleServiceClick` and to style the modal for desktop, which should be okay as it's full-screen, and add the navigation buttons to the header. I'm focusing on `pages/Home.tsx` now.


**Developing Navigation Controls**

I'm now integrating the navigation buttons. I've added `<` and `>` buttons within `ServiceModal.tsx` to handle previous and next service navigation. I've also implemented logic to correctly index and cycle through the services array. My primary task is to seamlessly connect these buttons to the service switching function and ensure smooth interaction within the modal.


**Adding Navigation Buttons**

I'm now integrating the navigation buttons. I'm adding `<` and `>` buttons to the ServiceModal header, positioned left of the close button, to simplify service switching. I'll need to hide the bottom floating navigation on desktop. The primary goal is to provide a seamless navigation experience within the modal across all devices. The header modification will apply to both mobile and desktop. I will ensure a high z-index for the modal overlay.


**Expanding Desktop Modal Access**

I'm now focused on enabling the service modal to open on desktop. This means ensuring the click functionality, currently triggered in `ServiceCard.tsx` and handled in `Home.tsx`, works universally. I need to remove the width check condition in the click handler in `Home.tsx` to achieve this. The core objective is to ensure the desktop experience mirrors mobile for service viewing.

Here are the changes to implement the service modal navigation on both Desktop and Mobile, as requested.

1.  **`pages/Home.tsx`**: I removed the mobile-only restriction so clicking a service card on Desktop now opens the modal instead of navigating away.
2.  **`components/ServiceModal.tsx`**:
    *   Added **Previous (`<`)** and **Next (`>`)** navigation buttons in the header, to the left of the Close button.
    *   Added keyboard support (Left/Right arrows to navigate, Escape to close).
    *   Hid the floating bottom navigation bar on Desktop (since the header controls are easier to use with a mouse).

J'ai corrigé le problème de défilement et de flou sur mobile.

**Explication technique du problème précédent :**
L'animation `animate-fade-in` sur le conteneur principal de la modale créait un "contexte d'empilement" (stacking context) et un bloc conteneur pour les éléments `fixed`. En conséquence, le menu "fixe" se positionnait par rapport à la modale (qui peut bouger ou être recalculée) plutôt que par rapport à l'écran du téléphone (viewport). De plus, l'opacité du fond était trop élevée (`98%`), rendant l'effet de flou imperceptible.

**Les corrections apportées dans `ServiceModal.tsx` :**

1.  **Suppression de l'animation sur la racine :** J'ai retiré `animate-fade-in` de la `div` principale (`fixed inset-0`) pour garantir que le positionnement `fixed` des enfants (le menu mobile) se réfère bien à la fenêtre du navigateur et non à la modale. L'animation est maintenant appliquée uniquement au contenu interne.
2.  **Menu Mobile Plein Écran Robuste :** Le menu mobile utilise maintenant `h-[100dvh]` (hauteur de viewport dynamique) pour gérer correctement la barre d'adresse mobile qui apparaît/disparaît, évitant les sauts de fond.
3.  **Transparence & Flou :** J'ai ajusté le fond à `bg-white/90` (au lieu de 98) pour que l'effet `backdrop-blur-xl` soit visible et persistant.
4.  **Bouton Fermer :** J'ai rendu le bouton "Fermer" en bas du menu plus visible (fond bleu/texte blanc) pour une action claire.

I'll need to modify the component to render the WhatsApp green circle with the icon and an added animation. The message will be the one described earlier, in French.


**Prioritizing Mobile Experience**

I've determined that the design shift will indeed be a floating WhatsApp button, directly replacing the current bar. The message itself, pre-populated for the user, is finalized. I'm prioritizing the mobile experience by making it fixed bottom right, floating, with a shadow, and z-index of 50. I'll make sure it's hidden on desktop screens, and it won't overlap any other page elements. I will begin by modifying the `StickyMobileBar.tsx` component and then I'll make sure it is fully responsive.


**Refining the UI Element**

I've stripped the "+" from the phone number for the WhatsApp link and also revised the pre-filled message to "Bonjour TM BTP, je souhaiterais obtenir un devis pour mon projet. **Executing the Design**

J'ai remplacé la barre permanente à trois boutons par un bouton flottant WhatsApp élégant et moins intrusif. 

Le bouton est positionné en bas à droite, avec une animation de pulsation discrète pour attirer l'attention sans gêner la navigation. Un message pré-rempli de demande de devis est automatiquement configuré pour le lien.

payload.text: J'ai publié mon site sur vercel mais cela affiche juste un fond blanc

**Debugging Deployment Issue**

I'm currently focused on why the site shows a blank white screen upon Vercel deployment. The user's input indicates a problem with the deployed version, contrasting with local functionality. Previous tasks, like navbar tweaks and the WhatsApp button, are now secondary. I'm investigating the deployment process itself to identify the root cause of this white-screen issue.


**Eliminating Navigation Clutter**

I've been examining the project's navigation flow, specifically service modals. My observations point toward a direct navigation strategy leveraging `react-router-dom` with `HashRouter` within `App.tsx`. I noticed an issue in `Icons.tsx` that may be leading to the "Blank Page" issue. While reviewing the project's imports, I determined that this setup is causing import and export issues with the `lucide-react` library.


**Isolating the Root Cause**

I'm now focusing on a critical oversight: the absent script tag in `index.html` referencing `index.tsx`. This likely explains the white screen, as the browser isn't loading the application's entry point. I've ruled out `HashRouter` as the primary problem. Now, I'm examining this missing script tag and other potential JavaScript errors in the browser console.


**Confirming Deployment Fixes**

Now I'm making several critical adjustments to address the white screen issue. First, I'm adding the essential `<script type="module" src="index.tsx"></script>` tag to `index.html`. After that, I will review that `index.tsx` is importing and rendering properly. I also need to ensure the App.tsx's routing logic is sound, as I received no errors. Simultaneously, I'll update the WhatsApp button behavior, based on previous comments. Finally, I will focus on diagnosing possible module resolution errors that might cause the blank screen on Vercel.


**Prioritizing Core File Stability**

I'm focused on stabilizing the core files to resolve the white screen issue and accommodate user requests. I'll begin by adding the missing script tag to `index.html` and verify correct importmap configuration. Next, I'll review `index.tsx` for any potential mount failures, and ensure `App.tsx` has correct routing and no circular dependencies. I'll also ensure `StickyMobileBar.tsx` is appropriately placed. Finally, I will remove or adjust `ServiceModal.tsx` as direct page navigation is now preferred.


**Addressing Rendering Bottlenecks**

I'm tackling rendering bottlenecks that might be caused by heavy modals.  I've detailed a fix that involves adding a script tag to `index.html`, refining navbar transitions for performance, ensuring `HashRouter` usage in `App.tsx`, and fixing issues in `StickyMobileBar.tsx`. My current focus is implementing these changes systematically, especially the transition refinements in `Navbar.tsx` to prevent background color lag. I am also working on the `StickyMobileBar.tsx` SVG and animation improvements.

C'est une erreur classique lors du passage d'un environnement de développement à une production sur Vercel : le fichier `index.html` n'appelait pas le point d'entrée JavaScript (`index.tsx`), et certaines importations de modules via `esm.sh` peuvent être sensibles à la manière dont elles sont déclarées.

Voici les corrections pour garantir l'affichage sur Vercel, tout en intégrant vos demandes (Navbar fluide, WhatsApp flottant et navigation directe).

### Modifications apportées :
1.  **index.html** : Ajout de la balise `<script type="module" src="index.tsx"></script>` indispensable pour charger l'application.
2.  **App.tsx** : Nettoyage des importations et sécurisation des routes.
3.  **Navbar.tsx** : Optimisation de la transition pour éviter le "fond blanc manquant" pendant le scroll.
4.  **StickyMobileBar.tsx** : Mise à jour du bouton WhatsApp flottant avec l'icône correcte et l'effet de pulsation.

entries.description: Ajout de l'appel au script module index.tsx pour corriger l'écran blanc lors du déploiement.
Correction du lag visuel de la navbar et amélioration de la transition mobile.
WhatsApp flottant avec message pré-rempli.
Optimisation des routes et suppression du modal pour une navigation directe plus stable.

payload.text:
Fix the following errors:

* `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'useRef')`

**Analyzing React Errors**

I've been drilling into a React error – `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'useRef')`. It's pointing towards a few common culprits. I suspect there might be conflicting React versions, a hook being misused outside a functional component, or a misconfigured `importmap`. Need to explore each one to zero in on the precise cause.


**Fixing Conflicting Imports**

I've just spotted a crucial issue in the `importmap` file. It's causing React to load from multiple sources, specifically conflicting versions of `react` and `react-dom`. The `importmap` defines `react` as `@19.0.0` while also using `^19.2.3` via the prefix map `react/`. This means different parts of the application might be using distinct React instances, which explains why hooks are failing. I need to simplify the importmap to have consistent versioning and resolve the source of the conflict.


**Consolidating React Versions**

I've just finished the import map cleanup, resolving the React version conflict. I've updated `index.html` to eliminate any possible version conflicts at the script inclusion level. Also, I've checked `ServiceCard.tsx`, which uses `useRef`, and that component's structure is fine. The `useRef` error should be resolved because all parts of the application now consistently use React version 19.0.0. I'm now focused on verifying that `react-router-dom` and `lucide-react` are also properly mapped to avoid any hidden conflicts.


**Revising Importmap**

I'm now overhauling the `importmap` to use a consistent React version across all imports, following the prior instructions and common practices. I noticed a subtle but critical issue: the existing map uses `react` and `react/` mappings, potentially resulting in conflicting React versions being loaded. This could easily trigger the `useRef` error, I need to clean the `importmap` within `index.html` to ensure that all React sub-imports uniformly use version 19.0.0. I'll maintain the `HashRouter` as requested previously, too.


**Checking Page Definitions**

I'm now investigating whether all the referenced pages, like `MaisonNeuve.tsx`, are properly defined. I need to confirm that `App.tsx` correctly renders these components based on the routes, and that these files are in the expected location. I also need to ensure that the previously mentioned `importmap` code is up-to-date and correctly imports all related dependencies. The latest changes clarify the import strategy and include necessary checks for any conflicting imports that could cause the `useRef` error, particularly in relation to the overall application structure.


**Verifying Vercel Setup**

I've been thinking about the Vercel deployment. Since it's a direct HTML/TSX setup, I must confirm that a transpilation step occurs somewhere, either automatically or through a specific build configuration. Without a build step or a Vercel-handled build, the `.tsx` files won't be executed in the browser. I have to verify the underlying setup for compatibility. I need to ensure Vercel's build process, if any, matches the provided project structure. The initial focus remains on resolving the `useRef` error, but deployment context is critical.


**Investigating Dispatcher Issue**

I'm now zeroing in on the root cause. While the `useRef` call itself seems sound, the underlying issue is likely the React internal dispatcher being null, which stems from React being initialized multiple times. The `index.html` structure seems normal for a specialized hosting setup. I must scrutinize `index.tsx` for any potential duplicate imports or initialization issues to confirm if the `importmap` alone is the problem.


**Validating Import Structure**

I'm now revisiting the import structure within my application. I see `React` and `ReactDOM` imports in the entry file, `index.tsx`, along with imports in `ServiceCard.tsx`, which seems good. I'm focusing on consistency in importing `lucide-react`, ensuring all components use `import { ... } from 'lucide-react'`. The `index.html` `importmap` is next. I am removing the trailing slash versions of the `react` and `react-dom` mappings to use specific versions. If `react-dom/client` is incorrectly mapped, that might be a culprit.

**Analyzing Build Environment**

I'm now investigating potential discrepancies between the local development and the Vercel deployment. Since the error persists even after import map adjustments, I suspect issues stemming from Vercel's build process. I'm focusing on ensuring that the `.tsx` files are correctly transpiled and that the necessary dependencies are bundled appropriately. A "fond blanc" often indicates a deployment failure, which could manifest as a dependency problem, a routing mishap, or an issue with how the static site is handled. I need to closely examine Vercel's setup.


**Addressing 'Fond Blanc'**

I'm now focusing on the 'fond blanc' the user mentioned. This hints at deployment failure, so I'm investigating the potential causes on Vercel. I need to closely examine Vercel's build process, as well as the dependency and routing. It appears that the issues are related to configuration. I need to ensure that the code is correctly transpiled, that all necessary dependencies are properly handled. The specific imports like `react-dom/client` must be handled correctly in all locations.


**Updating Root Creation**

I'm now changing `index.tsx` to align with modern React practices, using `createRoot` from `react-dom/client` instead of `ReactDOM`. The "fond blanc" deployment failure might have been due to an incorrect root creation. This adjustment should make the initialization more reliable. I've also checked `types.ts` for consistency in phone number formatting. I'm focusing on these adjustments, alongside the other investigations.


**Confirming React Initialization**

I'm now revising my import structure, particularly focusing on `index.tsx`. I noticed `ReactDOM` is being imported incorrectly, which could cause initialization issues. It should use `createRoot` from `react-dom/client` instead of `ReactDOM` for a cleaner initialization. That should solve the primary "fond blanc" issue. I've also verified `ServiceModal.tsx` is not utilized, so I'm focusing on the import setup and how components are initialized.


**Addressing Dual Issues**

I'm now focusing on fixing both the initialization error and the potential display issue. `index.tsx` is being revised to create the root using `createRoot` and correctly import the necessary dependencies from `react-dom/client`. This aligns with the new best practices. The goal is to ensure a smooth, modern React initialization and prevent the "fond blanc" and the underlying `useRef` problem. I'm checking to make sure there are no other conflicting import issues anywhere.

entries.description: Clean and consolidate the importmap to ensure a single, consistent version of React is loaded across the entire application. This fixes the 'Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading useRef)' which occurs when multiple React instances are present.

Correcting the import from react-dom/client to use the named export 'createRoot' instead of a default export, which is the standard for React 18+ and ensures compatibility with ESM providers like esm.sh.
